intro: Clinopodium graveolens, commonly known as wild thyme, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, pink to white flowers appear in whorls along the stems, and it produces small, four-lobed nutlets as seeds. Clinopodium graveolens is often used in traditional herbal medicine and as a culinary herb due to its aromatic properties.
